\forall \, z \in \Omega, \; F(z) = 
  \left[ 
  \begin{array}{cccc}
  f_{11}(z) & f_{12}(z) & \cdots & f_{1n}(z) \\
  \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\
  f_{m1}(z) & f_{12}(z) & \cdots & f_{mn}(z)
  \end{array}
  \right]

\forall \, z \in \Omega, \; F'(z) = 
  \left[ 
  \begin{array}{cccc}
  f'_{11}(z) & f'_{12}(z) & \cdots & f'_{1n}(z) \\
  \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\
  f'_{m1}(z) & f'_{12}(z) & \cdots & f'_{mn}(z)
  \end{array}
  \right]

\forall \, z \in \Omega, \; \int_{\gamma} F(z) \, dz = 
  \left[ 
  \begin{array}{cccc}
  \int_{\gamma} f_{11}(z) \,dz& \int_{\gamma} f_{12}(z) \,dz & \cdots & \int_{\gamma}f_{1n}(z)\,dz \\
  \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\
  \int_{\gamma}f_{m1}(z) \, dz& \int_{\gamma}f_{12}(z) \, dz& \cdots & \int_{\gamma}f_{mn}(z) \, dz
  \end{array}
  \right].
\forall \, z \in D(0,r(A)), \; F(z) = [I - zA]^{-1} = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} A_n z^n.

<!--
    The complement of $\Omega$ in $\mathbb{C}$ satisfies
      $$
      \mathbb{C} \setminus \Omega = \{z \in \mathbb{C} \; | \; \det (zI - A) = 0\}.
      $$
    The function $f: z \in \mathbb{C} \mapsto \det (zI - A)$ is a polynomial;
    it is nonzero (for example, $f(0) = \det I = 1$), thus it has a finite
    number of roots.
    They also form a closed set; its complement in $\mathbb{C}$, 
    which is $\Omega$, is open.
    -->

\forall \, z \in D(0,r), \; F(z) 
  = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} \frac{F^{(n)}(0)}{n!} z^n
  = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} A^n z^n.

\left|
     \left[
       \sum_{n=0}^{m} a_n t^n 
     \right] e^{-st} 
   \right|
   \leq 
   \left[
     \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} |a_n| t^n 
   \right] 
   e^{-(\mathrm{Re}(s)) t}
   = g(t) e^{-(\mathrm{Re}(s)) t}.

\left|
     \left[
       \sum_{n=0}^{m} |a_n| t^n
     \right] 
     e^{-st}
   \right|
   \leq
   \kappa e^{\sigma t} e^{-(\mathrm{Re}(s))t} 
   = 
   \kappa e^{-(\mathrm{Re}(s) - \sigma) t}.

\frac{1}{i2\pi}\int_{r[\circlearrowleft]} \overline{\mathcal{L}}[f] e^{st} \, ds
  =
  \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} n! a_n
  \frac{t^n}{n!}
  =
  \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} a_n t^n = f(t).

An *entire function of exponential type* is a holomorphic function 
$f:\mathbb{C} \to \mathbb{C}$ such that
  $$
  \exists \, \sigma > 0, \; \exists \, \kappa > 0, \;
  \forall \, z \in \mathbb{C}, \;
  |f(z)| \leq \kappa e^{\sigma|z|}.

**Preamble:** notation for (symmetric) open sectors:

  $$
  \Sigma(c, \alpha) =
  \{c + r e^{i\theta} \; | \; r>0, \; -\alpha < \theta < \alpha\}.
  $$

Let $\Omega$ be an open subset of $\mathbb{C}$ and
let $f: \Omega \to \mathbb{C}$ be a holomorphic function.
We assume that there is an angle $\alpha$ with $0 <\alpha < \pi/2$ 
such that
  $$
  \Sigma(0,\alpha)
  \subset \Omega
  $$
and that there are some $\sigma > 0$ and $\kappa > 0$ satisfying
  $$
  \forall \, z \in \Sigma, \;
  |f(z)| \leq \kappa e^{\sigma |z|}.
  $$



 1. Let $w \in \Sigma(0,\alpha)$.
    Describe the geometric structure of the set
      $$
      H_w = \{s \in \mathbb{C} \; | \; \mathrm{Re} \, (s w) > \sigma |w|\}.
      $$
    **This is vague. Ask more precise questions and/or asks for drawings
    in specific cases? Lift the question wrt the intersection here?
    Yes, and phrase it better. Ask for a full characterisation or just
    what we need?**

      $$
      H_w = \Sigma(\sigma e^{-i\arg w}, \pi/2).
      $$

    Show that there are $c\in \mathbb{C}$ and $0 < \beta < \pi/2$ such that
      $$
      \bigcap_{w \in \Sigma(0,\alpha)} \left\{H_{w} \; | \; w \in \Sigma(0,\alpha)\right\} = \Sigma(c, \beta)
      $$

    Same explicit stuff for the union ? Grpmh, no, it sucks.

 2. Show that for any $w \in \Sigma$ the function
      $$
      \mathcal{L}_w [f]:
      s \in H_w
      \mapsto 
      \int_{0}^{+\infty} f(t w) e^{-st w} w\, dt 
      $$
    is defined and holomorphic. 
    
 3. Show that the set of points $s$ that belong to $H_{w}$ for every 
    $w \in \Sigma$
    contains a non-empty open set $V$.

 4. Let $s \in V$; show the existence and compute the derivative of
      $$
      w \in \Sigma \mapsto \mathcal{L}_w [f].
      $$

    **NOTA:** there is a smart way. One you prove that the derivative
    exist, the directional derivative is zero in one direction ...
    That's fucking smart, I like it.

Answers
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. We notice that $L_0[f]$ is the Laplace transform of $f$,
   which is defined and holomorphic on 
   $H_0 = \{s \in \mathbb{C} \; | \; \mathrm{Re}(s) > \sigma\}$.
   Now, in general, if we define $f_{\beta}:\mathbb{R}_+ \to \mathbb{C}$ by
     $$
     f_{\beta}(t) = f(t e^{i\beta})
     $$
   then $L_{\beta} [f]$ is given by
     $$
     L_{\beta} [f](s) = e^{i\beta} L [f_{\beta}](se^{i\beta}),
     $$
   hence $L_{\beta}[f]$ is defined and holomorphic on $H_{\beta}$.


 4. Let $g(z) = f(z) e^{-sz}$, for $s \in V$
      $$
      \mathcal{L}_w [f](s) = \int_{0}^{+\infty} g(tw) w \, dt
      $$

    (formally)
      $$
      \partial_{w} \mathcal{L}_w [f](s) = 
      \int_{0}^{+\infty} (g'(tw) tw + g(tw)) \, dt
      $$
    (by integration by parts)
      $$
      \partial_{w} \mathcal{L}_w [f](s) = [g(tw) tw]^{+\infty}_0 = 0
      $$
   Hence, as the set ??? is connected, $w \mapsto \mathcal{L}_w [f](s)$ is constant.

Problem S
================================================================================

The exponential of a square matrix $A$ may be defined as the sum
  $$
  \exp A 
  = 
  I + A + \frac{1}{2}A^2 + \frac{1}{6} A^3+ \dots = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} \frac{1}{n!} A^n.
  $$
which is convergent (for example element-wise) for any choice of $A$; 
for the logarithm of a square matrix, the definition is more involved.
In the sequel, we use as an example the case of
  $$
  A = 
  \left[
  \begin{array}{rr}
  0 & -1 \\
  +1 & 0
  \end{array} 
  \right]
  $$

Let the $a_n$ be the coefficients such that
  $$
  \log z = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} a_n (z-1)^n
  $$
when $z$ belongs to the open disk of radius $1$ centered on $1$.
By analogy, we would like to defined $\log A$ as the matrix which is the sum of
  $$
  \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty} a_n (A - I)^n.
  $$
However, it doesn't work: prove that the sum is divergent (as in: there is
at least one element of the matrix that diverges).

Show that it fails and maybe that even with a new center this is bound to fail.
Hint: diagonalisation (not necessarily) ?



Compute the spectrum of $A$, defined as:
  $$
  \sigma(A) = \{z \in \mathbb{C} \; | \; \mathrm{det}\, (zI - A) = 0\}.
  $$
Let $\Omega = \mathbb{C} \setminus \sigma(A)$, compute $(zI - A)^{-1}$ 
for any $z\in \Omega$ and show that every element of this matrix
is a complex-differentiable function of $z$ in $\Omega$.


Let $\gamma$ be a sequence of closed rectifiable paths of 
$\Omega \setminus \mathbb{R}_-$ such that
  $$
  \forall \, z \in \sigma(A), \; \mathrm{ind}(\gamma, z) = 1.
  $$

Prove the identity first, before the log ?

  $$
  \log A = \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\gamma} (z I - A)^{-1} \log z \, dz.
  $$

Show that the definition is otherwise independent of $\gamma$.

Compute the result and $\exp(\log A)$ ($\exp$ defined classically).


Problem D
================================================================================

**Preamble.**
We search an alternate proof of the global version of Cauchy's integral formula.

Therefore, we forbid in this problem the use of the global integral
results (global versions of the integral theorem, residues theorem and of
course of Cauchy's formula). 
Everything else can be used 
(the results after the global theory chapter can actually 
be proved with the local version of Cauchy's integral theorem.)


----

Let $\Omega$ be an open set of $\mathbb{C}$, 
let $f:\Omega \to \mathbb{C}$ be a holomorphic function 
and let $\gamma$ be a sequence of rectifiable paths of $\Omega$.

 1. Let $z \in \mathrm{Ext} \, \gamma$. Show that the function
      $$
      w \mapsto \frac{f(w)}{w-z}
      $$
    is defined and continous on $\Omega$.

 2. We define
      $$
      \phi: z \in \mathrm{Ext} \, \gamma \mapsto \int_{\gamma} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} dw.
      $$ 
   Show that $\phi$ is holomorphic 
   (advice: compute the difference quotient $g(z+h) - g(z) /h$)


 3. We define the function $g: \Omega \times \Omega \to \mathbb{C}$ by
      $$
      g(w, z) = \frac{f(w) - f(z)}{w - z} \mbox{ if } w \neq z
      $$
   and
      $$
      g(w, w) = f'(w).
      $$
   Show that $g$ is continuous.

 4. Let $w \in \Omega$. 
    Show that the function $z \in \Omega \mapsto g(w, z)$ is holomorphic.

Let $\psi: \Omega \to \mathbb{C}$ be the function defined by
  $$
  \psi(z) = \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\gamma} g(w, z) dw.
  $$
The function $\psi$ is holomorphic 
(this is a consequence of the results of the previous questions.)

 5. Show that the function $\psi$ and $\phi$ have the same values on the 
   intersection of $\mathrm{Ext} \, \gamma$ and $\Omega$. 

We define the function $\chi: \mathbb{C} \to \mathbb{C}$ by
     $$
     \chi(z) = 
     \left|
     \begin{array}{ll}
     \psi(z) & \mbox{if } z \in \Omega, \\
     \phi(z) & \mbox{if } z \in \mathbb{C} \setminus \Omega.
     \end{array} 
     \right.
     $$

 6. Show that $\chi$ is holomorphic.

 7. Use this result to prove that $\psi = 0$.

 8. Prove that for every $z \in \Omega \setminus \gamma([0,1])$, 
    $$
    \mathrm{ind}(\gamma, z) \times f(z) 
    = 
    \frac{1}{i2\pi} \int_{\gamma} \frac{f(w)}{w-z} dw.
    $$
